title: How to Cook Dover Sole

steps.headline: Make a small incision in the dark skin at the base of the tail.
steps.description: Lightly use a chef’s knife to cut into the skin right above the tail. Dover sole skin is slightly thick and rubbery, so it will take a small amount of pressure to make the cut. Don’t cut entirely through the tail since this will make it more difficult to peel the skin off.

steps.headline: Peel the skin back towards the head.
steps.description: Use the blade of the knife to loosen enough skin from the sole so you can get a good grip. Place the heel of your non-dominant hand on the tail and use your dominant hand to pull the skin towards the head. As you approach the head of the fish, slow down so you don’t damage it. Hold the fish skin with a tea towel to get a better grip.

steps.headline: Flip the sole over and remove the white skin.
steps.description: Make another small incision near the tail and pull the white skin towards the head. Work slowly so the filets remain intact. Throw the skin away once you have it completely removed. Leave the white skin on if you plan to grill your sole.

steps.headline: Cut the whiskery ends with a pair of kitchen scissors.
steps.description: Cut along the sides of the fish, following the round edge. Start from the tail and work towards the head for the easiest removal. You can leave the whiskery ends on if you want to.

steps.headline: Season the sole with sea salt.
steps.description: Sprinkle the salt on your Dover sole with your fingers, using as much or as little as you want. Flip the sole over to coat both sides in seasoning. Use your hands to gently rub the salt into the fish so it absorbs the flavor.

steps.headline: Coat the fish in a thin layer of flour.
steps.description: Fill a shallow bowl or baking tray with 2 ounces (57 g) of flour. Lay the fish in the flour and cover each side with flour. Take the fish out of the flour and shake off the excess so it’s barely coated. Slap the sole once or twice to remove any extra flour that may not fall off on its own. Make sure the filets are dry before putting them in flour or else it could form clumps.

steps.headline: Add 3 US tbsp (44 ml) of vegetable oil to a skillet over medium heat.
steps.description: Pour the oil into the skillet so the bottom is coated evenly. Turn your stove to medium heat and let the oil heat and bubble. You can replace vegetable oil with any cooking oil of your choice.

steps.headline: Melt ½ tbsp (7 g) of unsalted butter in the oil.
steps.description: Drop the butter into the pan and move it around so it mixes with the oil. The oil prevents the butter from burning and the addition of butter will help add more flavor to your Dover sole. You can use salted butter if you’d like, but it may affect the overall saltiness of your fish. Sprinkle less salt in the beginning if you use unsalted butter.

steps.headline: Cook each side of the fish for 4 minutes.
steps.description: Lay the fish in the center of the pan and let it cook. After 4 minutes, use a spatula to flip the fish to the other side. The fish should be flaky and have a golden-brown color once it’s finished. Remove the fish from heat once it’s finished cooking. Check for an internal temperature of 145 °F (63 °C) before removing the sole from the heat.

steps.headline: Remove the lateral bones on the sides of the fish with a knife.
steps.description: Place the edge of the knife blade ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the outer edge of the fish. Push away from the center of the fish to remove the outer bones. Do this to each side of the fish. Once the fish is cooked, the meat will easily fall away from the bones.

steps.headline: Push the filets away from the backbone to remove it.
steps.description: Place your knife in between the two filets and push the filet away from the bone. Work slowly so the meat doesn’t fall apart. Repeat the process on the other side. Slide your knife under the backbone to separate it from the fish so it’s ready to serve. If you notice any of the bones break, make sure to pick them out of the filet before you eat them.

steps.headline: Serve the filets on a warm plate.
steps.description: Transfer the sole filets to a plate that you’ve heated in the microwave so your fish doesn’t get cold. Eat your fish while it’s still hot to maximize its flavor. Sole pairs well with rice pilaf or roasted vegetables.

steps.headline: Store the fish in the fridge for 3-4 days.
steps.description: Keep the fish in an airtight container or wrap it tightly in aluminum foil. Place any leftovers in the fridge within 2 hours after cooking it, or else you run the risk of bacteria forming on your fish. Cooked sole can be stored in the freezer for up to 3 months.

methods.name: Making Baked Dover Sole with Lemon

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Make sure one of the racks inside your oven is in the center position. Let the oven fully heat up before you cook anything.

steps.headline: Season each side of your sole with salt.
steps.description: Sprinkle salt on your fish using your fingers until you have the desired level of seasoning. Use as much or as little as you like, but be wary of over-salting the fish. If you’ve over salted the fish, you can rinse it off before you move on and start again.

steps.headline: Combine the melted butter and lemon juice in a bowl.
steps.description: Melt 2 teaspoons (10 g) of unsalted butter in the microwave and mix it with 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of lemon juice. Stir the mixture together thoroughly with a whisk. You can substitute olive oil for melted butter if needed.

steps.headline: Mix the flour, parsley, and pepper together in a shallow tray.
steps.description: Add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of flour, 2 teaspoons (2.5 g) of freshly chopped parsley, and ⅛ teaspoon (0.22 g) of black pepper to the baking tray. Use your hands or a dry whisk to combine the ingredients until they are completely mixed together. Add ⅛ teaspoon (0.22 g) of paprika to the mixture if you want to give your fish a little spice.

steps.headline: Dip the sole in the butter mixture and coat it in the flour mixture.
steps.description: Soak the sole in butter and lemon juice and shake off any excess liquid that drips off. Lay the sole flat in the tray with the flour, parsley, and pepper and lightly coat it. Pick it up and shake or pat off any clumps that form.

steps.headline: Place the filets on a non-stick baking tray and drizzle the butter on top.
steps.description: Put the Dover sole in the center of the baking tray and use any of the butter and lemon juice you have left to coat the fish. Wrap the baking tray in aluminum foil for an easy cleanup.

steps.headline: Bake the fish on the center rack for 15-20 minutes or until it’s golden brown.
steps.description: Keep the oven door closed while you cook the fish so heat doesn’t escape. When you think the fish is finished, use a fork to test if the meat is flaky.

steps.headline: Serve the filets on a hot plate.
steps.description:
Transfer the sole from the baking tray to a heated plate. Enjoy the fish immediately after it’s done cooking so it doesn’t get cold or lose any flavor..
Sprinkle parsley on top of the fish as a garnish.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the fish for 3-4 days.
steps.description: Keep the fish sealed in an airtight plastic container or a resealable bag. You can also wrap the fish tightly in aluminum foil. Put your leftovers in the fridge within 2 hours or else bacteria will form. Keep cooked sole in the freezer for up to 3 months.

steps.headline: Preheat your grill.
steps.description: Start your grill and cover it with the lid. Let it warm up for 15 minutes before you plan on cooking on it so it can cook the sole evenly. Use caution with lighter fluid when you light your grill.

steps.headline: Coat the top side of the sole with flour, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Put 2 ounces (57 g) of flour on a shallow baking tray and lay the fish so the skin side faces up. Lift the sole and wipe off any excess flour. Sprinkle salt and pepper onto the filet until you have the desired amount of seasoning. Only remove the dark skin when you grill sole. The white skin will go directly on the grill and crisp once it’s cooked.

steps.headline: Brush the sole with melted butter.
steps.description: Melt 2 ounces (57 g) of unsalted butter in the microwave in a bowl. Use a kitchen brush to lightly coat the top of the filet. Shake off any excess butter that drips off. Olive oil will work as a substitute for butter if needed.

steps.headline: Grill the fish with the skin side down for 5-6 minutes.
steps.description: Set the sole over direct heat so it cooks through. Cover the grill as soon as you place the fish on the grill. Avoid lifting the lid as much as you can so none of the heat escapes while it’s cooking. Check the temperature of the fish after 5 minutes to see if it’s cooked through. If you notice the skin burning on the fish, move it out of direct heat.

steps.headline: Flip the fish after 4 minutes if you want to have grill marks on the top.
steps.description: Use a spatula to carefully turn the fish over. Lay it gently back on the grill so the meat chars for 2 minutes. Slide the spatula underneath the fish again and flip it over to serve.

steps.headline: Serve the filets while they’re hot.
steps.description: Keep the filets on a warm plate so they don’t lose any temperature. Enjoy your meal while it’s still warm with lemon and rice.

steps.headline: Store the fish in the fridge for up to 4 days.
steps.description: Keep the fish in an airtight container or wrap it tightly in aluminum foil. Put leftovers in the fridge within 2 hours or else harmful bacteria can form on your fish. Cooked sole can be stored in the freezer for up to 3 months.
